Several countries have demonstrated the
support for Ukraine
through
political and economic sanctions
with the aim of forcing Russian President Vladimir Putin to back down. Another support was the
sending weapons.
Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukrainian President,
refuses to leave the country
.
People of all nationalities have performed
protests around the world
over the last few days and Portugal was no exception. Also
Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa
attended, last Saturday,
next to the Belém Palace
in a demonstration of affection and solidarity.

Tennis player leaves Ukraine and leaves his parents behind: "We love you very much"
Dayana Yastremska, current number 120 in the world tennis hierarchy, took to social media this Sunday to announce that
left Ukraine
, in the company of her younger sister, due to the resulting invasion of the country by Russian military forces.
2:57 pm -
Ukrainian women make Molotov cocktails to help fight the war
They are not armed, but they help to fight. Not only do Ukrainian men defend their country, but women do too. In the video it is possible to see Ukrainian women preparing homemade chemical weapons, called 'Molotov cocktails'.
Honderden vrijwilligers maken in Dnipro molotovcocktails

US announces $54 million in additional humanitarian aid
The United States approved
54 million dollars
(48.1 million euros) of additional humanitarian aid to Ukraine, the head of US diplomacy, Antony Blinken, announced today. "It is with the well-being of ordinary Ukrainians in mind that we announce the provision of nearly $54 million in humanitarian aid to those affected by the new Russian invasion," Blinken said in a statement.
2:45 pm -
Pope Francis calls for the “urgent” opening of humanitarian corridors
Pope Francis today called on the international community to open
"urgently" humanitarian corridors
to welcome refugees fleeing Ukraine and seeking refuge from the Russian invasion, considering that "those who wage war forget humanity".
2:37 pm -
Portugal "doing everything" to guarantee safe reception of Ukrainians
The Portuguese authorities are
"doing everything"
to ensure that Ukrainian citizens who want to take refuge in Portugal can do so "in safe conditions, with all possible integration", said the Secretary of State for Internal Administration today.
2:31 pm -
Dozens of Portuguese mobilized in Krakow to help refugees
Several dozen Portuguese people participate in Krakow, Poland, in
refugee aid effort
from Ukraine, and at least one of them hosted a Ukrainian family, Nuno Gonçalves, who emigrated to the country eight years ago, revealed to Lusa today.
2:22 pm -
Borrell proposes financing lethal material through the European Fund
The European Union's High Representative for Foreign Affairs, Josep Borrell, will today propose to the 27 Member States the
financing with common funds
the supply of "lethal material" so that Ukraine can defend itself against the Russian invasion.
2:09 pm -
There are no Russian troops in Kiev." Mayor confirms death of nine civilians
Vitali Klitschko, the mayor of Kiev, assured, this Sunday afternoon, that
"there are no Russian troops"
in the Ukrainian capital. In a message posted on the social network Instagram, the former boxing champion also confirmed that, since the Russian invasion began, nine civilians - including a child - and 18 military personnel have died in the city.

Zelensky confirms negotiations with Moscow on the border with Belarus"
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky
confirmed that negotiations between Kiev and Moscow will take place this Sunday
on the Belarusian-Ukrainian border, Sky News reports. According to a statement from Ukraine, delegations of
two countries meet "without preconditions" near the Pripyat river
. This decision was taken after Alexander Lukashenko, president of Belarus, spoke with the Ukrainian president.
"Alexander Lukashenko took responsibility for ensuring that all planes, helicopters and missiles on Belarusian territory will remain on the ground during the trip, negotiations and the return of the Ukrainian delegation", the statement read.
Oleksandr Lukashenko has called Volodymyr Zelenskyy.
The politicians agreed for the Ukrainian delegation to meet with the Russian delegation with no preconditions on the Ukraine-Belarus border in the vicinity of Pripyat river.

Russian protesters detained in St. Petersburg
Russian police disperse people gathering at an anti-war demonstration in Saint Petersburg, Russia. While the population can be heard shouting:
"We don't want war"
and clapping, you see
the police detaining and attacking protesters
, images that were presented by CNN Portugal, and, later, placed on buses.
1:23 p.m.
-
Putin puts nuclear deterrent forces on high alert
Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered the military command to
nuclear deterrence forces be placed on alert
, following the latest statements by NATO countries, which they believe are intensifying tension between Russia and the West, reports Reuters.
According to The Guardian, the order, announced by the TASS news agency, is the result of a meeting between Putin, Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and the Chief of Staff of the Russian Armed Forces, Valery Gerasimov. “The senior officials of the main NATO countries also allow aggressive statements against our country, which is why I order the Minister of Defense and the Chief of Staff [of the Russian Armed Forces] to transfer the deterrence forces of the Russian army to carry out combat duty in a special way,” Putin said in the statement.
Here's Putin just now ordering Russia's deterrence (nuclear) forces on "a special regime of duty" in response to foreign sanctions. It's a DEFCON situation.
pic.twitter.com/Hhmq5ZAMmO
— Kevin Rothrock (@KevinRothrock)
February 27, 2022
1:05 p.m.
-
France closes airspace to Russian planes
After countries like Germany, Belgium, Luxembourg or Italy, the
France became the latest country
to close its airspace to Russian planes, according to a publication by the Minister of Transport, Jean-Baptiste Djebbari, made this Sunday. "France will close airspace to all Russian planes and airlines from tonight," he said.
France is shutting its airspace to all Russian aircraft and airlines from this evening on. To the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Europe responds with total unity.
— Jean-Baptiste Djebbari (@Djebbari_JB)
February 27, 2022

-
Belarus will join the invasion, says former Ukrainian defense minister
Former Ukrainian Defense Minister Andriy Zagorodnyuk said this Sunday that Belarus is about to declare war on Ukraine,
according to the Guardian
.
"It is highly likely that the Republic of Belarus will join Russia in the war against Ukraine. On the side of the Russians. There is information about Belarusian pilots boarding planes to enter Ukraine"
, indicated the former ruler.

Ukrainian forces have regained control of second-largest city, says governor
Ukrainian forces have regained control of Kharkiv, regional governor Oleg Sinegubov said today, hours after announcing an advance by the Russian army and street fighting in Ukraine's second city.
"Kharkiv is under our complete control",
wrote Sinegubov on social media, quoted by the French agency AFP.
Sinegubov said that a
"elimination of enemies in the city"
.
12:46
-
Putin accuses Kiev of not taking advantage of the opportunity to negotiate
Russian President Vladimir Putin today accused Ukraine of not taking advantage of "the opportunity" for talks that it wants to impose on Belarus, the country from where Russia launched part of the invasion of Ukraine.
"The Russian delegation is in the Belarusian city of Gomel and is ready to negotiate with representatives from Kiev. They, showing inconsistency, have not taken advantage of this opportunity until now"
, declared Putin during a telephone call with Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett,
according to a statement from the Kremlin
.
12:45
-
Fighting intensity decreases in Kiev and increases in Kharkiv
The intensity of the fighting in Kiev decreased last night compared to the previous night, but
increased in the second Ukrainian city, Kharkiv
, according to an assessment released today by the British Ministry of Defense on the social network Twitter.
"Ukrainian forces faced remnants of Russian irregular forces inside the city of Kiev for the second night in a row, the fighting has been of lower intensity than the previous night"
, said the British Ministry of Defense, cited by the North American agency AP.
Russian forces in Kupyansk, Kharkiv region

Germany offers free trains for refugees
Germany will allow all Ukrainian refugees from Poland to travel free of charge on long-distance trains from today,
announced the state company Deutsche Bahn
.

-
Kiev launches website for Russians to find out the fate of dead soldiers
Ukrainian authorities
launched today
a website that allows those close to Russian soldiers killed in combat in the country to find out about their fate, as Russia does not publicize its losses.

Sadiq Khan calls on government to provide Ukrainians with 'safe route' to refuge
London Mayor Sadiq Khan said Ukrainian civilians seeking refuge should not have to complete "complicated visa applications" when fleeing a war zone. On social media he asked the government to provide "safe routes" for Ukrainians.
Ukrainian civilians looking for refuge should not be filling out complicated visa applications when they are fleeing a war zone.
London has a long history of giving asylum to those in need. The Government must urgently provide safe routes for sanctuary. 🇺🇦

Germany invests in the army and more than 2% of GDP in Defense
Germany will allocate a
extraordinary budget of 100,000 million
of euros to equip its armed forces and will make an annual investment of more than 2% of the gross domestic product (GDP) in Defense, the German Chancellor announced today.

Zelensky asks the International Criminal Court to intervene against Moscow
Ukraine has asked the International Criminal Court to order Moscow to
cease hostilities
, the Ukrainian President announced today. "We are asking for an urgent decision ordering Russia to stop the activity, and we hope that the hearings will begin next week," Zelensky wrote on his Twitter account.
Ukraine has submitted its application against Russia to the ICJ. Russia must be held accountable for manipulating the notion of genocide to justify aggression. We request an urgent decision ordering Russia to cease military activity now and expect trials to start next week.

"Color revolutions" and Putin's revenge
Russia's military invasion of Ukraine, in addition to the Kremlin's official arguments about
"demilitarization and denazification"
of the neighboring country, is also being seen as a personal revenge by the Russian President in light of recent internal political developments.
11h26 -
With the invasion of Ukraine, we entered a new era"
German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said today at an extraordinary session of the German parliament (Bundestag) that the world has entered
"in a new era"
after the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
11:15 am -
There are around 368 thousand refugees in neighboring countries"
About
368,000 refugees fled
of fighting in Ukraine to neighboring countries, since the Russian invasion launched on Thursday, and the number continues to increase, the United Nations indicated today.

Oliveira do Hospital available to receive refugees from Ukraine
The municipality of Oliveira do Hospital expressed its willingness to welcome refugees from Ukraine. "Faced with the appeals of international institutions we cannot remain insensitive and
We have a duty to be supportive
towards the Ukrainian people, who are currently experiencing one of the saddest moments in their history", said the president of the Municipal Council of Oliveira do Hospital, José Francisco Rolo.

Russia expects Ukrainian response on negotiations by 12 p.m.
Russia will wait
until 3pm local time
(12:00 in Lisbon or GMT) for a response from Ukraine about holding negotiations in the Belarusian city of Gomel, despite the Ukrainian President having already rejected this proposal.
10:47 -
"Fuck you." Soldiers who defended Zmiinyi island may be alive
This Sunday, the Ukrainian State Border Guard posted a message on social media stating that
13 Ukrainian soldiers
who were believed to have died defending the island of Zmiinyi may, after all, be alive.

Czech Republic also does not want to face Russia at the 2022 World Cup
The Czech Republic announced today that
will not face Russia
if the two teams qualify for the play-off final for the 2022 football World Cup, as a form of protest against the invasion of Ukraine by Russian troops.
10:23 am -
Liz Truss. Conflict in Ukraine could last "several years"
British Foreign Minister Liz Truss admitted today that the conflict in Ukraine
can last "several years"
because of Russia's "significant forces", which may try to use "even worse weapons". "The UK absolutely supports Ukraine throughout this very long and difficult conflict," he said.

Zelensky wants Russia expelled from the UN Security Council
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy today defended the
expulsion from Russia
of the United Nations (UN) Security Council for considering that the invasion of Ukraine amounts to an act of genocide.

Russian troops in the north of Kharkiv

More than 4,000 Russian soldiers killed in Ukraine
The Deputy Minister of Defense of Ukraine, Hanna Malya, reported that, to date, around 4,300 Russian soldiers have died during the invasion, a number that she said is yet to be confirmed. According to Sky News, Russia has lost 146 tanks, 27 planes and 26 helicopters so far.

Zelensky welcomes formation of international "coalition" to help Ukraine
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky today welcomed the formation of a
international "coalition"
of countries providing aid to Ukraine, on the fourth day of the Russian invasion of their country.

Putin praises "heroism" of special operations forces
Russian President Vladimir Putin today highlighted the
heroism of special operations forces
of his country, in a congratulatory message on the occasion of the celebration of the day of that body of the Armed Forces.

Belarusian leader asks Ukraine to negotiate with Russia

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said today that the night "was tough" in the country, with Russian bombings hitting inhabited areas.
"Last night was tough, again shooting, again bombing of residential neighborhoods, of civil infrastructures. There is nothing today that the occupier does not consider a legitimate target"

Kiev "survived the night"

. Zelensky reacted, via a video message, to information provided by the Kremlin, according to which a Russian delegation arrived today in the Belarusian city of Gomel for talks with Ukrainian government officials.

The deaths of at least
64 civilians
, as well as 240 injured citizens, says Swiss Info based on a report from the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), which reads: "At 5pm on 26 February, the OHCHR [Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights] reports at least 240 injured civilians, including at least 64 deaths".

Germany
will take this measure this Sunday from 3pm (2pm in Lisbon), announced the Ministry of Transport.

title: Putin coloca em alerta máximo forças nucleares de dissuasão russas
original_title: Putin coloca em alerta máximo forças nucleares de dissuasão russas
translated_title: Putin puts Russian nuclear deterrent forces on high alert
original_text:
Início
Internacional
Putin coloca em alerta máximo forças nucleares de dissuasão russas
A ordem foi dada no quarto dia de combates na Ucrânia, devido a "declarações agressivas" do Ocidente.
O presidente russo, Vladimir Putin
© EPA/ALEKSEY NIKOLSKYI/SPUTNIK/KREMLIN
DN/Lusa
27 Fevereiro 2022 — 13:01
Facebook
Twitter
Comentar
Partilhar
Tópicos
Internacional
Rússia
Ucrânia
Vladimir Putin
Volodymyr Zelensky
Relacionados
internacional
Ucrânia: Papa apela ao "silêncio das armas" e diz-se de "coração ferido"
guerra na ucrânia
Zelenskiy anuncia encontro entre delegações russa e ucraniana
guerra na ucrânia
Milhares de pessoas em Lisboa manifestam-se em apoio à Ucrânia
O Presidente da Rússia, Vladimir Putin, mandou este domingo colocar em alerta máximo as forças de dissuasão nucleares russas devido a "declarações agressivas" do Ocidente.
"Ordeno ao ministro da Defesa e ao chefe de Estado-Maior que ponham a força dissuasora do exército russo em alerta especial de combate", disse Putin numa reunião televisiva com os seus chefes militares, citada pela agência AFP.
A ordem foi dada no quarto dia de combates na Ucrânia, que Putin mandou invadir na quinta-feira.
Fechar
Subscreva as newsletters
Diário de Notícias
e receba as informações em primeira mão.
Subscrever
"Os países ocidentais não só estão a tomar medidas hostis contra o nosso país na esfera económica, como também altos funcionários dos principais membros da NATO fizeram declarações agressivas em relação ao nosso país", disse Putin durante a reunião, segundo televisão russa.
Em reação, o ministro das Relações Exteriores da Ucrânia disse que Kiev não vai ceder nas negociações com a Rússia, acusando Putin de tentar aumentar a "pressão".
"Não nos vamos render, não vamos capitular, não vamos desistir de um único centímetro do nosso território", declarou Dmytro Kuleba numa conferência de imprensa transmitida online.
Os Estados Unidos, por sua vez, afirmaram que Putin está "a fabricar ameaças".
"Este é um padrão do presidente Putin que temos visto ao longo deste conflito, que está a fabricar ameaças que não existem para justificar novas agressões", disse a secretária de imprensa da Casa Branca, Jen Psaki, ao canal ABC.
Exército reassume controlo de Kharkiv, sanções à Rússia aumentam
A Ucrânia continua a resistir ao ataque russo e reassumiu o controlo de Kharkiv, a segunda maior cidade do país, enquanto no estrangeiro se reforça o envio de ajuda e se multiplicam as medidas para penalizar a Rússia.
As forças ucranianas reassumiram o controlo de Kharkiv, disse hoje o governador regional, Oleg Sinegubov, horas depois de ter anunciado um avanço do exército russo e combates de rua na segunda cidade da Ucrânia.
"Kharkiv está sob o nosso total controlo", escreveu Sinegubov nas redes sociais, citado pela agência francesa AFP.
As autoridades ucranianas tinham anunciado de madrugada a entrada do exército russo em Kharkiv (norte) e o cerco de duas cidades no sul da Ucrânia, Kherson e Berdiansk, no quarto dia da invasão do país.
Segundo o Ministério da Saúde da Ucrânia, pelo menos 198 civis, incluindo três crianças, foram mortos e 1.115 pessoas ficaram feridas desde quinta-feira. A ONU registou no sábado pelo menos 64 mortos entre civis e centenas de milhares de pessoas sem água ou eletricidade.
Dezenas de militares ucranianos perderam a vida nos combates e Kiev, que reivindica ter matado 4.300 soldados russos e que hoje lançou um 'site' que permite que parentes de soldados russos conheçam seu destino. Moscovo mantém silêncio sobre as suas perdas.
Aos ataques russos contra aeródromos e refinarias ucranianas, os Estados Unidos e a União Europeia, entre outros, responderam com o envio de armas e munições para a Ucrânia e o reforço de sanções para isolar ainda mais Moscovo.
Vários países, incluindo Alemanha, França, Itália, países escandinavos e do Benelux, anunciaram hoje o encerramento do seu espaço aéreo a aviões russos. No sábado, o Ocidente excluiu numerosos bancos russos do sistema internacional de pagamentos Swift, essencial para os fluxos financeiros mundiais, uma decisão à qual o Japão aderiu hoje.
Tóquio anunciou ainda que entregará mais armas à Ucrânia, como prometeram nas últimas horas vários países incluindo a Alemanha - que rompeu com a sua política tradicional de não exportar armas para zonas de conflito e vai enviar mil lança-roquetes anti-tanque e 500 mísseis terra-ar -- e Portugal, que mandará espingardas G3, granadas e diverso equipamento militar como coletes e capacetes.
Washington prometeu uma nova ajuda militar de 350 milhões de dólares (310,5 milhões de euros).
O Presidente ucraniano, Volodymyr Zelensky, disse que Kiev pediu ao Tribunal Internacional de Justiça, em Haia, que ordene a Moscovo uma cessão das hostilidades.
"Vassylkiv, Cherniguiv, Sumi, Kharkiv e muitas outras cidades vivem em condições que não víamos (...) desde a Segunda Guerra Mundial", indicou, acusando a Rússia de considerar as áreas habitadas "como um alvo legítimo".
Zelensky elogiou a formação de uma "coligação antiguerra" internacional para apoiar a Ucrânia e convocou os estrangeiros para irem lutar "contra os criminosos de guerra russos" na "Legião Internacional" que está a ser formada no país.
Desde quinta-feira, cerca de 368.000 refugiados fugiram dos combates na Ucrânia para os países vizinhos, segundo a ONU. A Polónia registou à volta de 156.000 e a Alemanha tornou gratuitos os comboios para todos os ucranianos em fuga.
O Papa Francisco apelou à abertura "urgente" de corredores humanitários e pediu o fim do conflito.
Mas o exército russo, cujo "heroísmo" foi saudado pelo Presidente Vladimir Putin, recebeu no sábado ordens para alargar a ofensiva, devido ao facto de Kiev ter recusado negociações.
Entretanto, a presidência da Ucrânia anunciou que concordou em participar em conversações com a Rússia na fronteira com a Bielorrússia, perto de Chernobyl, após mediação do Presidente bielorrusso, Alexander Lukashenko.

translated_text:
Home
International
Putin puts Russian nuclear deterrent forces on high alert
The order was given on the fourth day of fighting in Ukraine, due to "aggressive statements" from the West.
Russian President Vladimir Putin
© EPA/ALEKSEY NIKOLSKYI/SPUTNIK/KREMLIN
DN/Lusa
27 February 2022 — 13:01
Facebook
Twitter
Comment
Share
Topics
International
Russia
Ukraine
Vladimir Putin
Volodymyr Zelensky
Related
international
Ukraine: Pope calls for "silence of arms" and says he has a "wounded heart"
war in ukraine
Zelenskiy announces meeting between Russian and Ukrainian delegations
war in ukraine
Thousands of people in Lisbon demonstrate in support of Ukraine
The President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, this Sunday ordered Russian nuclear deterrence forces to be placed on high alert due to "aggressive statements" from the West.
"I order the Minister of Defense and the Chief of Staff to put the deterrent force of the Russian army on special combat alert," Putin said in a televised meeting with his military chiefs, cited by the AFP agency.
The order was given on the fourth day of fighting in Ukraine, which Putin ordered invaded on Thursday.
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
"Not only are Western countries taking hostile measures against our country in the economic sphere, but senior officials of the main NATO members have made aggressive statements towards our country," Putin said during the meeting, according to Russian television.
In reaction, Ukraine's Foreign Minister said that Kiev will not give in in negotiations with Russia, accusing Putin of trying to increase "pressure".
"We will not surrender, we will not capitulate, we will not give up a single centimeter of our territory", declared Dmytro Kuleba in a press conference broadcast online.
The United States, in turn, stated that Putin is "manufacturing threats".
"This is a pattern from President Putin that we have seen throughout this conflict, who is fabricating threats that don't exist to justify further aggression," White House press secretary Jen Psaki told ABC.
Army resumes control of Kharkiv, sanctions on Russia increase
Ukraine continues to resist the Russian attack and has regained control of Kharkiv, the country's second largest city, while abroad the sending of aid is increasing and measures to penalize Russia are multiplying.
Ukrainian forces have regained control of Kharkiv, regional governor Oleg Sinegubov said today, hours after announcing an advance by the Russian army and street fighting in Ukraine's second city.
“Kharkiv is under our complete control,” Sinegubov wrote on social media, quoted by the French agency AFP.
Ukrainian authorities had announced early in the morning the entry of the Russian army into Kharkiv (north) and the siege of two cities in southern Ukraine, Kherson and Berdiansk, on the fourth day of the invasion of the country.
According to Ukraine's Ministry of Health, at least 198 civilians, including three children, have been killed and 1,115 people injured since Thursday. On Saturday, the UN recorded at least 64 civilian deaths and hundreds of thousands of people without water or electricity.
Dozens of Ukrainian soldiers lost their lives in the fighting in Kiev, which claims to have killed 4,300 Russian soldiers and which today launched a website allowing relatives of Russian soldiers to find out about their fate. Moscow remains silent about its losses.
To Russian attacks against Ukrainian airfields and refineries, the United States and the European Union, among others, responded by sending weapons and ammunition to Ukraine and strengthening sanctions to further isolate Moscow.
Several countries, including Germany, France, Italy, Scandinavian and Benelux countries, today announced the closure of their airspace to Russian planes. On Saturday, the West excluded numerous Russian banks from the Swift international payments system, essential for global financial flows, a decision Japan joined today.
Tokyo also announced that it will deliver more weapons to Ukraine, as several countries have promised in the last few hours, including Germany - which broke with its traditional policy of not exporting weapons to conflict zones and will send a thousand anti-tank rocket launchers and 500 surface-to-air missiles - and Portugal, which will send G3 rifles, grenades and various military equipment such as vests and helmets.
Washington promised new military aid of 350 million dollars (310.5 million euros).
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Kiev has asked the International Court of Justice in The Hague to order Moscow to cease hostilities.
"Vassylkiv, Cherniguiv, Sumi, Kharkiv and many other cities live in conditions that we have not seen (...) since the Second World War", he said, accusing Russia of considering the inhabited areas "as a legitimate target".
Zelensky praised the formation of an international "anti-war coalition" to support Ukraine and called on foreigners to go and fight "against Russian war criminals" in the "International Legion" being formed in the country.
Since Thursday, around 368,000 refugees have fled fighting in Ukraine for neighboring countries, according to the UN. Poland registered around 156,000 and Germany made trains free for all fleeing Ukrainians.
Pope Francis called for the "urgent" opening of humanitarian corridors and called for an end to the conflict.
But the Russian army, whose "heroism" was hailed by President Vladimir Putin, received orders on Saturday to expand the offensive, due to the fact that Kiev refused negotiations.
Meanwhile, the Ukrainian presidency announced that it agreed to participate in talks with Russia on the border with Belarus, near Chernobyl, after mediation by Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko.

A Federação Internacional de Judo (FIJ) suspendeu hoje o estatuto de presidente honorário e embaixador do organismo do líder russo, Vladimir Putin, devido à invasão da Ucrânia pela Rússia.

Na altura, Vizer justificou a distinção afirmando que Putin era "uma das personalidades que garantem os valores do judo no mundo".
Vladimir Putin, 69 anos, praticou judo desde muito cedo e alcançou o cinturão preto aos 18 anos, tendo sido campeão regional na cidade natal, São Petersburgo.
Numa entrevista em 2001, disse ter sido um mestre do desporto e que encarava o judo como uma filosofia.

Autor de um livro sobre judo, Putin admitiu, em 2014, que gostaria de ter sido atleta olímpico desta modalidade.
A Rússia invadiu novamente a Ucrânia na quinta-feira, depois de ter anexado a península ucraniana da Crimeia em 2014.
No quarto dia de combates, as forças ucranianas continuam a resistir apesar da diferença das forças armadas dos dois países vizinhos.
A invasão foi condenada pela generalidade da comunidade internacional e levou vários países e a União Europeia (UE) a impor sanções económicas a interesses e personalidades russas, incluindo a Putin e ao seu chefe da diplomacia, Sergei Lavrov.

Ukraine: International Judo Federation suspends Putin's honorary title

Vladimir Putin

Writing with Lusa
27 February 2022 at 10:16
Vladimir Putin, 69, practiced judo from an early age and achieved his black belt at the age of 18, having been regional champion in his hometown, Saint Petersburg
The International Judo Federation (IFJ) today suspended the status of honorary president and ambassador of the organization of Russian leader, Vladimir Putin, due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
Related
Modalities.
Ukraine: Portuguese Olympians want to boycott competitions with Russians and Belarusians
Modalities.

"Taking into account the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, the International Judo Federation announces the suspension of Vladimir Putin's status as Honorary President and Ambassador of the Federation", announced the IFJ in a short statement cited by the French agency AFP.
Based in Paris, the IJF is chaired by Austrian Marius Vizer, who awarded Putin the eighth "dan", one of the highest degrees in judo, in 2012.

International
Another English club tried to sign Luis Díaz: "I spoke to him on the phone..."
West Ham manager David Moyes admitted that the club came close to signing the former FC Porto Colombian winger.
At the time, Vizer justified the distinction by stating that Putin was "one of the personalities who guarantee the values ​​of judo in the world".
Vladimir Putin, 69 years old, practiced judo from an early age and achieved his black belt at the age of 18, having been regional champion in his hometown, Saint Petersburg.
In an interview in 2001, he said he was a master of the sport and that he viewed judo as a philosophy.
Also read
FC Porto

Statements by Sérgio Conceição, coach of FC Porto, at a press conference in anticipation of the reception to Gil Vicente, counting for the 24th round of the Bwin League, scheduled for 8:30 pm on Sunday.
Author of a book on judo, Putin admitted, in 2014, that he would like to have been an Olympic athlete in this sport.
Russia invaded Ukraine again on Thursday, after annexing Ukraine's Crimean peninsula in 2014.
On the fourth day of fighting, Ukrainian forces continue to resist despite the difference in the armed forces of the two neighboring countries.
The invasion was condemned by most of the international community and led several countries and the European Union (EU) to impose economic sanctions on Russian interests and personalities, including Putin and his head of diplomacy, Sergei Lavrov.
The invasion also had numerous repercussions in the world of professional sport, with competitions being transferred, games against Russia being refused by national teams, Russian athletes being declared "persona non grata" and sponsors being called into question.

title: Kiev lança site para russos identificarem soldados mortos e conhecerem o seu destino
original_title: Kiev lança site para russos identificarem soldados mortos e conhecerem o seu destino — DNOTICIAS.PT
translated_title: Kiev launches website for Russians to identify dead soldiers and find out their fate — DNOTICIAS.PT
original_text:
A Guerra
Mundo
Kiev lança site para russos identificarem soldados mortos e conhecerem o seu destino
Agência Lusa
27 fev 2022
12:01
0
Comentários
As autoridades ucranianas lançaram hoje uma página na Internet que permite aos próximos de soldados russos mortos em combate no país conhecerem o seu destino, uma vez que a Rússia não divulga as suas perdas.
No quarto dia da invasão da Ucrânia pela Rússia, a página, batizada "
200rf.com
", em referência ao código usado pelos soldados mortos em combate, passa a divulgar fotos de passaportes ou documentos militares pertencentes a soldados russos alegadamente mortos desde a invasão do país.
São, ainda, divulgados vídeos de soldados russos alegadamente feitos prisioneiros, bem como o nome e local de origem de alguns deles.
Ищи своих
"Sei que numerosos russos querem saber como e onde estão os seus familiares, os seus filhos, os seus maridos, e o que lhes aconteceu", explica, num vídeo colocado no site, Viktor Andrusiv, conselheiro do ministro do Interior ucraniano.
Segundo Kiev, o Exército ucraniano matou mais de 4.300 soldados russos e fez prisioneiros perto de 200. Moscovo não divulgou nenhum dado sobre as perdas sofridas desde o início da ofensiva, na madrugada da passada quinta-feira.
O dirigente da República russa do Daguestão, no Cáucaso, Serguei Melikov, foi o primeiro responsável a reconhecer, hoje, a morte de um soldado russo na Ucrânia.
Na sua página oficial no Instagram, Melikov prestou uma homenagem a um oficial que, segundo escreveu, foi morto durante "a operação especial de defesa do Donbass", no leste da Ucrânia.
O regulador russo dos media ordenou sábado a supressão dos conteúdos dos meios de comunicação do país de todas as referências a civis mortos pelo Exército russo na Ucrânia, bem como os termos "invasão", "ofensiva" ou "declaração de guerra".
Moscovo é acusada de, desde o início da crise com a Ucrânia, em 2014, camuflar as suas perdas militares entre os que combateram apoiando os separatistas pró russos no Leste. Este apoio foi sempre desmentido, até à invasão em curso.
O político liberal russo Lev Schlossberg sugeriu, recentemente, que o Exército russo utilize crematórios móveis para queimar os corpos dos soldados mortos em combate.
"Não há guerra. Não há mortos. Não há baixas. As pessoas simplesmente desaparecem. Para sempre", escreveu no seu blogue.
A Rússia lançou na quinta-feira de madrugada uma ofensiva militar na Ucrânia, com forças terrestres e bombardeamento de alvos em várias cidades, que já provocaram cerca de 200 mortos, incluindo civis, e mais de 1.100 feridos, em território ucraniano, segundo Kiev. A ONU deu conta de perto de 370 mil deslocados para a Polónia, Hungria, Moldávia e Roménia.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, disse que a "operação militar especial" na Ucrânia visa desmilitarizar o país vizinho e que era a única maneira de a Rússia se defender, precisando o Kremlin que a ofensiva durará o tempo necessário.
O ataque foi condenado pela generalidade da comunidade internacional e motivou reuniões de emergência de vários governos, incluindo o português, e da Organização do Tratado do Atlântico Norte (NATO), UE e Conselho de Segurança da ONU, tendo sido aprovadas sanções em massa contra a Rússia.
Rússia e Ucrânia

translated_text:
The War
World
Kiev launches website for Russians to identify dead soldiers and find out their fate
Lusa Agency
Feb 27, 2022
12:01
0
Comments
Ukrainian authorities today launched a website that allows those close to Russian soldiers killed in combat in the country to find out about their fate, as Russia does not publicize its losses.
On the fourth day of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the page, named "
200rf.com
", in reference to the code used by soldiers killed in combat, starts publishing photos of passports or military documents belonging to Russian soldiers allegedly killed since the invasion of the country.
Videos of Russian soldiers allegedly taken prisoner are also released, as well as the names and place of origin of some of them.
Ищи своих
"I know that many Russians want to know how and where their relatives, their children, their husbands are, and what happened to them", explains, in a video posted on the website, Viktor Andrusiv, advisor to the Ukrainian Interior Minister.
According to Kiev, the Ukrainian Army killed more than 4,300 Russian soldiers and took close to 200 prisoners. Moscow has not released any data on the losses suffered since the beginning of the offensive, in the early hours of last Thursday.
The leader of the Russian Republic of Dagestan, in the Caucasus, Serguei Melikov, was the first person responsible to recognize, today, the death of a Russian soldier in Ukraine.
On his official Instagram page, Melikov paid tribute to an officer who, he wrote, was killed during "the special operation to defend Donbass" in eastern Ukraine.
The Russian media regulator ordered Saturday the suppression of the country's media content of all references to civilians killed by the Russian Army in Ukraine, as well as the terms "invasion", "offensive" or "declaration of war".
Moscow is accused of, since the beginning of the crisis with Ukraine in 2014, camouflaging its military losses among those who fought supporting pro-Russian separatists in the East. This support was always denied, until the ongoing invasion.
Liberal Russian politician Lev Schlossberg recently suggested that the Russian Army use mobile crematoriums to burn the bodies of soldiers killed in combat.
"There is no war. There are no deaths. There are no casualties. People simply disappear. Forever," he wrote on his blog.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused around 200 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), EU and UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

title: França endurece sanes contra Rússia e reforça apoio de defesa a Kiev
original_title: França endurece sanções contra Rússia e reforça apoio de defesa a Kiev — DNOTICIAS.PT
translated_title: France toughens sanctions against Russia and reinforces defense support for Kiev — DNOTICIAS.PT
original_text:
A Guerra
Mundo
França endurece sanções contra Rússia e reforça apoio de defesa a Kiev
Agência Lusa
26 fev 2022
23:45
0
Comentários
França decidiu hoje endurecer as sanções contra a Rússia e reforçar o apoio à Ucrânia em equipamentos de defesa na sequência do conflito entre os dois países do leste europeu.
As decisões foram tomadas no Conselho de Defesa e Segurança, que hoje se reuniu sob convocação do Presidente francês, Emmanuel Macron.
No plano militar, França comprometeu-se a fazer uma "entrega adicional de equipamentos de defesa às autoridades ucranianas e apoio em combustível", referiu uma nota da Presidência, sem precisar o tipo de armamento que será dado.
O reforço das sanções à Rússia visa, nomeadamente, o acesso à plataforma interbancária Swift e os bens financeiros de personalidades russas.
Algumas das novas sanções serão tomadas pela França em coordenação com outros países da União Europeia.
França decidiu também, em sede do Conselho de Defesa e Segurança, adotar medidas contra "a propaganda" russa sobre a guerra na Ucrânia.
O Presidente francês falou hoje ao telefone com o homólogo bielorrusso, Alexander Lukashenko, sobre "a posição e o papel da Bielorrússia no conflito", indicou Minsk.
Segundo um comunicado da Presidência bielorrussa, Lukashenko disse que o seu país, aliado da Rússia, estava disposto a acolher "conversações de paz".
A Rússia lançou na quinta-feira de madrugada uma ofensiva militar na Ucrânia, com forças terrestres e bombardeamento de alvos em várias cidades, que já provocaram pelo menos 198 mortos, incluindo civis, e mais de 1.100 feridos, em território ucraniano, segundo Kiev. A ONU deu conta de 150.000 deslocados para a Polónia, Hungria, Moldávia e Roménia.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, afirmou que a "operação militar especial" na Ucrânia visa desmilitarizar o país vizinho e que era a única maneira de a Rússia se defender, precisando o Kremlin que a ofensiva durará o tempo necessário.
O ataque foi condenado pela generalidade da comunidade internacional e motivou reuniões de emergência de vários governos, incluindo o português, da Organização do Tratado do Atlântico Norte (NATO), União Europeia e Conselho de Segurança da ONU, tendo sido aprovadas sanções em massa contra a Rússia.

translated_text:
The War
World
France toughens sanctions against Russia and reinforces defense support for Kiev
Lusa Agency
Feb 26, 2022
23:45
0
Comments
France today decided to tighten sanctions against Russia and reinforce support for Ukraine in defense equipment following the conflict between the two Eastern European countries.
The decisions were taken at the Defense and Security Council, which met today at the call of the French President, Emmanuel Macron.
On the military front, France committed to making an "additional delivery of defense equipment to the Ukrainian authorities and fuel support", said a note from the Presidency, without specifying the type of weapons that will be given.
The strengthening of sanctions on Russia aims, in particular, at access to the Swift interbank platform and the financial assets of Russian personalities.
Some of the new sanctions will be taken by France in coordination with other European Union countries.
France also decided, at the Defense and Security Council, to adopt measures against Russian "propaganda" about the war in Ukraine.
The French President spoke on the phone today with his Belarusian counterpart, Alexander Lukashenko, about "the position and role of Belarus in the conflict", said Minsk.
According to a statement from the Belarusian Presidency, Lukashenko said that his country, an ally of Russia, was willing to host "peace talks".
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least 198 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 150,000 displaced people to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin stating that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the European Union and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

title: Rússia espera resposta ucraniana sobre negociaes até s 15 horas locais
original_title: Rússia espera resposta ucraniana sobre negociações até às 15 horas locais — DNOTICIAS.PT
translated_title: Russia expects Ukrainian response on negotiations by 3 pm local time — DNOTICIAS.PT
original_text:
A Guerra
Mundo
Rússia espera resposta ucraniana sobre negociações até às 15 horas locais
Agência Lusa
27 fev 2022
11:08
0
Comentários
Foto AFP
A Rússia vai aguardar até às 15:00 locais (12:00 em Lisboa ou GMT) por uma resposta da Ucrânia sobre a realização de negociações na cidade bielorrussa de Gomel, apesar de o Presidente ucraniano já ter recusado esta proposta.
O anúncio do prazo, para uma resposta por parte dos ucranianos, foi feito hoje pelo assessor da Presidência russa e chefe da delegação negociadora, Vladimir Medinski, segundo avançam as agências internacionais.
O porta-voz do Kremlin, Dmitri Peskov, disse hoje que representantes dos "ministérios dos Negócios Estrangeiros, da Defesa e de outros serviços, designadamente da presidência russa" chegaram à cidade de Gomel, na Bielorrússia, para negociar com os responsáveis ucranianos.
"A delegação russa está pronta para começar e agora esperamos pelos ucranianos", disse o mesmo porta-voz, citado pelas agências internacionais. A cidade indicada pelos russos para as negociações foi Gomel.
Numa mensagem e vídeo em que reage à proposta russa, o Presidente ucraniano, Volodymyr Zelensky, disse que o seu país está pronto para negociações de paz com a Rússia, mas não na Bielorrússia.
Volodymyr Zelensky indicou Varsóvia, Bratislava, Istambul, Budapeste ou Baku como locais alternativos para decorrerem as negociações.
O Presidente ucraniano considerou ainda que há outros locais possíveis para que delegações de ambos os países se possam sentar à mesa de negociações, mas deixou claro que a Ucrânia não aceita a escolha feita pela Rússia -- de que decorram na Bielorrússia.
A Rússia invadiu a Ucrânia na quinta-feira, através da Bielorrússia ao norte, da Crimeia, território ucraniano que anexou em 2014, ao sul, e do território russo a nordeste e a leste.
As autoridades ucranianas contabilizaram já a morte de pelo menos 198 pessoas, incluindo civis, desde o início da invasão russa.
O ataque russo tem sido amplamente condenado em todo o mundo e vários países, com destaque para os ocidentais, aprovaram sanções económicas para punir o regime de Moscovo.
renegociar contratos
Rússia e Ucrânia

translated_text:
The War

Russia expects Ukrainian response on negotiations by 3pm local time
Lusa Agency
Feb 27, 2022
11:08
0

AFP Photo
Russia will wait until 15:00 local time (12:00 in Lisbon or GMT) for a response from Ukraine about holding negotiations in the Belarusian city of Gomel, despite the Ukrainian President having already rejected this proposal.
The announcement of the deadline for a response from the Ukrainians was made today by the advisor to the Russian Presidency and head of the negotiating delegation, Vladimir Medinski, according to international agencies.
Kremlin spokesman Dmitri Peskov said today that representatives of the "ministries of Foreign Affairs, Defense and other services, particularly the Russian presidency" arrived in the city of Gomel, in Belarus, to negotiate with Ukrainian officials.
"The Russian delegation is ready to start and now we are waiting for the Ukrainians," said the same spokesman, quoted by international agencies. The city indicated by the Russians for negotiations was Gomel.
In a message and video reacting to the Russian proposal, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said that his country is ready for peace negotiations with Russia, but not in Belarus.
Volodymyr Zelensky indicated Warsaw, Bratislava, Istanbul, Budapest or Baku as alternative locations for negotiations to take place.
The Ukrainian President also considered that there are other possible places for delegations from both countries to sit at the negotiating table, but made it clear that Ukraine does not accept the choice made by Russia -- which will take place in Belarus.
Russia invaded Ukraine on Thursday, through Belarus to the north, Crimea, Ukrainian territory it annexed in 2014, to the south, and Russian territory to the northeast and east.
Ukrainian authorities have already counted the deaths of at least 198 people, including civilians, since the start of the Russian invasion.
The Russian attack has been widely condemned around the world and several countries, especially Western ones, have approved economic sanctions to punish the Moscow regime.

title: Ucrânia .  Somos gratos por cada mão amiga . Mas não é suficiente
original_title: Ucrânia. "Somos gratos por cada mão amiga. Mas não é suficiente"
translated_title: Ukraine. "We are grateful for every helping hand. But it is not enough"
original_text:
K
aterina Fonseca voltou a recorrer ao Instagram para deixar uma nova mensagem ao mundo onde fala da guerra na Ucrânia, pedindo ajuda para combater a invasão russa.
"Falo para as pessoas na Europa, América, Rússia, no mundo.
Há uma guerra a decorrer na Ucrânia. Não é uma 'operação especial', mas uma guerra cínica e cruel. Cidades e aldeias estão em chamas.
Há rockets da Rússia e da Bielorrússia a voar em direção a edifícios residenciais de vários andares. Isto é o que eu e milhões de ucranianos vemos com os nossos próprios olhos", foi com estas palavras que Katerina Fonseca começou a recente publicação que fez na sua página de Instagram, este domingo, 27 de fevereiro.
"
Os loucos Fuhrers enviam os soldados para matar ucranianos, que dão as suas vidas a defender o país natal, as mulheres e os filhos. Esta é a única verdade e não há outra
", destacou de seguida a mulher do treinador português Paulo Fonseca, que vive em Kiev.
"
Não acreditem se disserem que o nosso governo é 'nazi'. O governo ucraniano em Kiev, juntamente com nosso exército, defende o seu país e o seu povo pacífico. Não acreditem em nada, exceto que no centro da Europa agora há uma guerra sangrenta e brutal contra ucranianos pacíficos que lutam pela liberdade. Ajudem a parar esta guerra
", suplicou.
"Perguntem aos vossos amigos e colegas na Rússia - por que razão os seus soldados lutam e morrem na Ucrânia? Por que executam ordens criminosas para matar civis? Este é o nosso país, a nossa terra, tudo aqui é estranho para eles! Eles devem voltar para as suas casas e deixar a nossa em paz", acrescentou.
"
As cidades ucranianas estão hoje a pegar fogo. Hoje as nossas crianças estão em abrigos antiaéreos sem comida. Hoje atingiram um autocarro com refugiados ucranianos e não deixaram uma ambulância passar. Quem pode saber que cidades e países serão bombardeados amanhã?
", continuou.
"
O mundo inteiro está agora ao lado da Ucrânia. Vemos e somos gratos por cada mão amiga que nos é estendida. Mas hoje não é suficiente! Enquanto as bombas continuarem a cair e os ucranianos continuarem a morrer, isso não é suficiente. Não queremos guerra.
Parem com esta guerra louca. Parem", rematou.
Ver esta publicação no Instagram
Uma publicação partilhada por Katerina Fonseca (Ostroushko) (@fonseca.katerina)

translated_text:
K
aterina Fonseca once again turned to Instagram to leave a new message to the world where she talks about the war in Ukraine, asking for help to combat the Russian invasion.
"I speak to people in Europe, America, Russia, the world.
There is a war going on in Ukraine. It is not a 'special operation', but a cynical and cruel war. Cities and villages are on fire.
There are rockets from Russia and Belarus flying towards multi-story residential buildings. This is what I and millions of Ukrainians see with our own eyes", it was with these words that Katerina Fonseca began the recent post she made on her Instagram page, this Sunday, February 27th.
"
The crazy Fuhrers send soldiers to kill Ukrainians, who give their lives defending their home country, their wives and their children. This is the only truth and there is no other
", then highlighted the wife of Portuguese coach Paulo Fonseca, who lives in Kiev.
"
Don't believe me if they say our government is 'Nazi'. The Ukrainian government in Kiev, together with our army, defends its country and its peaceful people. Do not believe anything, except that in the center of Europe there is now a bloody and brutal war against peaceful Ukrainians fighting for freedom. Help stop this war
", he pleaded.
"Ask your friends and colleagues in Russia - why do their soldiers fight and die in Ukraine? Why do they carry out criminal orders to kill civilians? This is our country, our land, everything here is alien to them! They should go back to their homes and leave ours alone," he added.
"
Ukrainian cities are burning today. Today our children are in bomb shelters without food. Today they hit a bus with Ukrainian refugees and didn't let an ambulance pass. Who can know which cities and countries will be bombed tomorrow?
", he continued.
"
The whole world is now on Ukraine's side. We see and are grateful for every helping hand extended to us. But today is not enough! As long as the bombs continue to fall and Ukrainians continue to die, that is not enough. We don't want war.
Stop this crazy war. Stop," he concluded.

A post shared by Katerina Fonseca (Ostroushko) (@fonseca.katerina)

title: Portugal envia equipamento militar : G3 , coletes , capacetes e granadas
original_title: Portugal envia equipamento militar: G3, coletes, capacetes e granadas
translated_title: Portugal sends military equipment: G3, vests, helmets and grenades
original_text:
Início
Política
Portugal envia equipamento militar: G3, coletes, capacetes e granadas
A Bélgica, os Países Baixos, a França e a República Checa, entre outros, também anunciaram entregas de armas e combustível às forças ucranianas.

Portugal vai enviar equipamento militar para a Ucrânia, nomeadamente espingardas G3, coletes, capacetes ou granadas, informou este sábado o Ministério da Defesa Nacional. Numa nota enviada às redações sobre o apoio à Ucrânia, o ministério refere que, "a pedido das autoridades ucranianas, Portugal irá disponibilizar equipamento militar".
Da lista do material fazem parte "coletes, capacetes, óculos de visão noturna, granadas e munições de diferentes calibres, rádios portáteis completos, repetidores analógicos e espingardas automáticas G3", enumera o Ministério da Defesa Nacional.
A Bélgica, os Países Baixos, a França e a República Checa, entre outros, também anunciaram entregas de armas e combustível às forças ucranianas, respondendo aos pedidos de ajuda de Kiev.

Subscrever
Berlim anunciou que a Alemanha tinha decidido entregar "o mais rapidamente possível" à Ucrânia mil lança-roquetes e 500 mísseis terra-ar do tipo
stinger
para ajudar o país a defender-se da invasão militar da Rússia, uma decisão que foi saudada pelo Presidente ucraniano, Volodymyr Zelensky.
O Governo alemão anunciou também o envio para a Ucrânia de 14 veículos blindados, bem como de 10 mil toneladas de combustível, que serão entregues "via Polónia".
"A defesa europeia está em ação para apoiar a Ucrânia, (nós) facilitaremos a entrega de ajuda militar", disse na rede social Twitter Charles Michel, presidente do Conselho Europeu (órgão que representa os Estados-membros).
A Rússia lançou na quinta-feira de madrugada uma ofensiva militar na Ucrânia, com forças terrestres e bombardeamento de alvos em várias cidades, que já provocaram pelo menos 198 mortos, incluindo civis, e mais de 1.100 feridos, em território ucraniano, segundo Kiev. A ONU deu conta de 150.000 deslocados para a Polónia, Hungria, Moldávia e Roménia.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, disse que a "operação militar especial" na Ucrânia visa desmilitarizar o país vizinho e que era a única maneira de a Rússia se defender, precisando o Kremlin que a ofensiva durará o tempo necessário.
O ataque foi condenado pela generalidade da comunidade internacional e motivou reuniões de emergência de vários governos, incluindo o português, e da Organização do Tratado do Atlântico Norte (NATO), UE e Conselho de Segurança da ONU, tendo sido aprovadas sanções em massa contra a Rússia.

Portugal sends military equipment: G3, vests, helmets and grenades
Belgium, the Netherlands, France and the Czech Republic, among others, also announced deliveries of weapons and fuel to Ukrainian forces.
© EPA/ALISA YAKUBOVYCH

Portugal will send military equipment to Ukraine, namely G3 rifles, vests, helmets or grenades, the Ministry of National Defense reported this Saturday. In a note sent to newsrooms about support for Ukraine, the ministry states that, "at the request of the Ukrainian authorities, Portugal will provide military equipment".
The list of materials includes "vests, helmets, night vision goggles, grenades and ammunition of different calibers, complete portable radios, analogue repeaters and G3 automatic rifles", lists the Ministry of National Defense.
Belgium, the Netherlands, France and the Czech Republic, among others, also announced deliveries of weapons and fuel to Ukrainian forces, responding to Kiev's requests for help.

Berlin announced that Germany had decided to deliver "as quickly as possible" to Ukraine a thousand rocket launchers and 500 surface-to-air missiles of the type
stinger
to help the country defend itself from Russia's military invasion, a decision that was welcomed by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.
The German Government also announced the sending of 14 armored vehicles to Ukraine, as well as 10 thousand tons of fuel, which will be delivered "via Poland".
"European defense is in action to support Ukraine, (we) will facilitate the delivery of military aid," Charles Michel, president of the European Council (the body that represents member states), said on Twitter.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least 198 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 150,000 displaced people to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), EU and UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

title: Rússia visa aeroportos e refinarias ; EUA e UE enviam mais armas
original_title: Rússia visa aeroportos e refinarias; EUA e UE enviam mais armas
translated_title: Russia targets airports and refineries; US and EU send more weapons
original_text:
E
normes explosões iluminaram o céu no início de hoje a sul da capital, Kiev, onde as pessoas se abrigam nas suas casas e espaços subterrâneos para se protegerem de um ataque em grande escala por parte das forças russas.
Um depósito de petróleo perto do aeroporto de Zhuliany, a cerca de 40 quilómetros a sul da capital, está em chamas, atingido num ataque russo, segundo o gabinete do Presidente, Volodymyr Zelensky, e o presidente da câmara da cidade vizinha de Vasylkiv.
O gabinete de Zelensky também disse que as forças russas fizeram explodir outras instalações de combustível em Kharkiv, a segunda maior cidade do país, levando o governo a avisar as pessoas para se protegerem do fumo, cobrindo as janelas com panos húmidos.
As forças ucranianas mantêm as suas posições e os combates decorrem "nos mesmos locais de há três dias", disse hoje o assessor presidencial ucraniano Mikhail Podoliak.
Homens, mulheres e crianças aterrorizados procuraram segurança dentro das casas e em espaços subterrâneos, e o Governo manteve um recolher obrigatório de 39 horas para manter as pessoas fora das ruas.
Mais de 150.000 ucranianos fugiram para a Polónia, Moldávia e outros países vizinhos, e as Nações Unidas avisaram que o número poderia aumentar para quatro milhões se os combates se intensificassem.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, não revelou os seus planos finais, mas as autoridades ocidentais acreditam que está determinado a derrubar o Governo da Ucrânia e substituí-lo por um regime pró-russo, redesenhando o mapa político da Europa e reavivando a influência que Moscovo tinha na era da Guerra Fria.
Para ajudar a Ucrânia a resistir, EUA e outros países europeus prometeram o reforço da ajuda militar à Ucrânia, com a Alemanha a fechar o espaço aéreo aos aviões russos.
Os EUA, a União Europeia e o Reino Unido concordaram em bloquear bancos russos do sistema global de transações financeiras SWIFT, que movimenta dinheiro em torno de mais de 11.000 bancos e outras instituições financeiras em todo o mundo, parte de uma nova ronda de sanções que visam Moscovo, prometendo ainda impor "medidas restritivas" ao banco central da Rússia.
O Ministério da Defesa britânico afirmou que "a velocidade do avanço russo abrandou temporariamente, como resultado provável de dificuldades logísticas agudas e de uma forte resistência ucraniana".
Um alto funcionário da defesa dos EUA disse que mais de metade da potência de combate russa que se encontrava concentrada ao longo das fronteiras da Ucrânia tinha entrado no país e que Moscovo teve de comprometer mais combustível e outras unidades de apoio dentro da Ucrânia do que inicialmente previsto.
Pequenos grupos de tropas russas foram detetadas dentro de Kiev, mas o Reino Unido e os EUA disseram que o grosso das forças estava a 30 quilómetros do centro da cidade, na tarde de sábado.
A Rússia afirma que o seu ataque à Ucrânia a partir do norte, leste e sul visa apenas alvos militares, mas pontes, escolas e bairros residenciais foram atingidos.
O ministro da saúde da Ucrânia informou no sábado que 198 pessoas, incluindo três crianças, tinham sido mortas e mais de 1.000 outras ficaram feridas durante a maior guerra terrestre da Europa desde a Segunda Guerra Mundial.
Um míssil atingiu um edifício de apartamentos no sudoeste de Kiev, perto de um dos dois aeroportos da cidade. Um socorrista disse que seis civis ficaram feridos.
A embaixadora da Ucrânia nos EUA, Oksana Markarova, afirmou que as tropas em Kiev estavam a combater "grupos de sabotagem" russos. A Ucrânia garantiu que cerca de 200 soldados russos foram capturados e milhares mortos.
Markarova disse que a Ucrânia estava a recolher provas de bombardeamentos de áreas residenciais, jardins de infância e hospitais para as submeter a Haia como possíveis crimes contra a humanidade.
Zelensky reiterou a sua abertura às conversações com a Rússia numa mensagem de vídeo, dizendo que saudava uma oferta da Turquia e do Azerbaijão para organizarem esforços diplomáticos.
O Kremlin confirmou um telefonema entre Putin e o Presidente do Azerbaijão, Ilham Aliyev, mas não deu qualquer pista sobre o reinício das conversações. Um dia antes, Zelensky ofereceu-se para negociar a principal exigência russa: abandonar as ambições de aderir à NATO.

translated_text:
And
Massive explosions lit up the sky early today south of the capital, Kiev, where people took shelter in their homes and underground spaces to protect themselves from a large-scale attack by Russian forces.
An oil depot near Zhuliany airport, about 40 kilometers south of the capital, is on fire, hit in a Russian attack, according to the office of the President, Volodymyr Zelensky, and the mayor of the neighboring city of Vasylkiv.
Zelensky's office also said Russian forces blew up other fuel installations in Kharkiv, the country's second-largest city, prompting the government to warn people to protect themselves from smoke by covering windows with damp cloths.
Ukrainian forces maintain their positions and the fighting is taking place "in the same places as three days ago", Ukrainian presidential advisor Mikhail Podoliak said today.
Terrified men, women and children sought safety inside homes and underground spaces, and the government maintained a 39-hour curfew to keep people off the streets.
More than 150,000 Ukrainians have fled to Poland, Moldova and other neighboring countries, and the United Nations has warned that the number could rise to four million if fighting intensifies.
Russian President Vladimir Putin has not revealed his final plans, but Western officials believe he is determined to overthrow Ukraine's government and replace it with a pro-Russian regime, redrawing the political map of Europe and reviving the influence that Moscow had in the Cold War era.
To help Ukraine resist, the US and other European countries promised to increase military aid to Ukraine, with Germany closing airspace to Russian planes.
The US, the European Union and the United Kingdom have agreed to block Russian banks from the SWIFT global financial transaction system, which moves money around more than 11,000 banks and other financial institutions around the world, part of a new round of sanctions targeting Moscow, while also promising to impose "restrictive measures" on Russia's central bank.
The British Ministry of Defense stated that "the speed of the Russian advance has temporarily slowed, as a likely result of acute logistical difficulties and strong Ukrainian resistance".
A senior US defense official said that more than half of the Russian combat power that was concentrated along Ukraine's borders had entered the country and that Moscow had to commit more fuel and other support units inside Ukraine than initially anticipated.
Small groups of Russian troops were detected inside Kiev, but the UK and US said the bulk of the forces were within 30 kilometers of the city center on Saturday afternoon.
Russia says its attack on Ukraine from the north, east and south is aimed only at military targets, but bridges, schools and residential neighborhoods have been hit.
Ukraine's health minister reported Saturday that 198 people, including three children, had been killed and more than 1,000 others were injured during Europe's biggest land war since World War II.
A missile hit an apartment building southwest of Kiev, near one of the city's two airports. A rescuer said six civilians were injured.
Ukraine's ambassador to the US, Oksana Markarova, said troops in Kiev were fighting Russian "sabotage groups". Ukraine assured that around 200 Russian soldiers were captured and thousands killed.
Markarova said Ukraine was collecting evidence of bombings of residential areas, kindergartens and hospitals to submit to The Hague as possible crimes against humanity.
Zelensky reiterated his openness to talks with Russia in a video message, saying he welcomed an offer from Turkey and Azerbaijan to organize diplomatic efforts.
The Kremlin confirmed a phone call between Putin and Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev, but gave no hint about the resumption of talks. A day earlier, Zelensky offered to negotiate Russia's main demand: abandoning ambitions to join NATO.

title: Mriya . Rússia destrói o ( único ) Antonov An - 225 , o maior avião do mundo
original_title: 'Mriya'. Rússia destrói o (único) Antonov An-225, o maior avião do mundo
translated_title: 'Mriya'. Russia destroys the (only) Antonov An-225, the largest plane in the world
original_text:
O
Antonov-225 'Mriya', de fabricação ucraniana, foi destruído num ataque russo ao aeródromo de Hostomel, perto de Kiev. Esta era a única aeronave deste modelo que existia no mundo e o maior avião de carga existente, construído como parte do programa espacial soviético.
O Antonov-225 foi, mais recentemente, uma preciosa ajuda durante a pandemia da Covid-19, pois permitiu o transporte de enormes quantidades de material médico de uma só vez em viagens entre a Ásia e a Europa.
A destruição do 'Mriya' - que significa 'Sonho', em português - foi já confirmada na conta da Ucrânia no Twitter: "O maior avião do mundo foi destruído pelos russos num aeródromo perto de Kiev. Vamos reconstruir o avião. Cumpriremos nosso sonho de uma Ucrânia forte, livre e democrática", pode ler-se.
The biggest plane in the world "Mriya" (The Dream) was destroyed by Russian occupants on an airfield near Kyiv. We will rebuild the plane. We will fulfill our dream of a strong, free, and democratic Ukraine.
pic.twitter.com/Gy6DN8E1VR
— Ukraine / Україна (@Ukraine)
February 27, 2022
Também Dmytro Kuleba, ministro dos Negócios Estrangeiros da Ucrânia, escreveu, na mesma rede social, sobre a perda do avião. "Esta foi a maior aeronave do mundo, AN-225 'Mriya' ('Sonho'). A Rússia pode ter destruído o nosso ‘Mriya’. Mas nunca poderão destruir o nosso sonho de um Estado europeu forte, livre e democrático. Vamos prevalecer!", destacou.
This was the world’s largest aircraft, AN-225 ‘Mriya’ (‘Dream’ in Ukrainian). Russia may have destroyed our ‘Mriya’. But they will never be able to destroy our dream of a strong, free and democratic European state. We shall prevail!
pic.twitter.com/TdnBFlj3N8
— Dmytro Kuleba (@DmytroKuleba)
February 27, 2022
Com 84 metros de comprimento, uma envergadura de 88 metros e um trem de aterragem de 32 rodas, o An-225, de que só existia um exemplar, podia transportar até cerca de 250 toneladas de carga a velocidades até 850 quilómetros por hora.

Ukrainian-made Antonov-225 'Mriya' was destroyed in a Russian attack on Hostomel airfield, near Kiev. This was the only aircraft of this model in existence in the world and the largest cargo plane in existence, built as part of the Soviet space program.
The Antonov-225 was, more recently, a valuable help during the Covid-19 pandemic, as it allowed the transport of huge amounts of medical material at once on trips between Asia and Europe.
The destruction of the 'Mriya' - which means 'Dream' in Portuguese - has already been confirmed on Ukraine's Twitter account: "The largest plane in the world was destroyed by the Russians at an airfield near Kiev. We will rebuild the plane. We will fulfill our dream of a strong, free and democratic Ukraine", it can be read.
The biggest plane in the world "Mriya" (The Dream) was destroyed by Russian occupants on an airfield near Kyiv. We will rebuild the plane. We will fulfill our dream of a strong, free, and democratic Ukraine.

February 27, 2022
Dmytro Kuleba, Minister of Foreign Affairs of Ukraine, also wrote, on the same social network, about the loss of the plane. "This was the largest aircraft in the world, AN-225 'Mriya' ('Dream'). Russia may have destroyed our 'Mriya'. But they can never destroy our dream of a strong, free and democratic European state. We will prevail!", he highlighted.
This was the world’s largest aircraft, AN-225 ‘Mriya’ (‘Dream’ in Ukrainian). Russia may have destroyed our ‘Mriya’. But they will never be able to destroy our dream of a strong, free and democratic European state. We shall prevail!
pic.twitter.com/TdnBFlj3N8

February 27, 2022

title: Zelensky diz ter falado hoje com Presidente da Bielorrússia
original_title: Zelensky diz ter falado hoje com Presidente da Bielorrússia — DNOTICIAS.PT
translated_title: Zelensky says he spoke to the President of Belarus today — DNOTICIAS.PT
original_text:
A Guerra
Mundo
Zelensky diz ter falado hoje com Presidente da Bielorrússia
Agência Lusa
27 fev 2022
12:52
0
Comentários
O Presidente ucraniano, Volodymyr Zelensky, disse hoje ter falado com o seu homólogo bielorrusso, Alexander Lukashenko, aliado de Moscovo e cujo país é utilizado como base de apoio pela Rússia.
"Falei com Alexander Lukashenko", disse Zelensky no Facebook, sem adiantar detalhes, num momento em que a Rússia insiste na realização de eventuais negociações neste país.
Numa anterior declaração, o Presidente ucraniano havia afirmado que o seu país está pronto para negociações de paz com a Rússia, na Polónia, Hungria, Turquia ou Azerbaijão, ou em qualquer outro país, mas não "de onde mandam mísseis" em direção à Ucrânia, numa referência à Bielorrússia.
Zelensky reagia, através de uma mensagem de vídeo, às informações avançadas pelo Kremlin, segundo os quais uma delegação russa chegou hoje à cidade bielorrussa de Gomel para conversações com responsáveis do governo ucraniano.
A Rússia declarou que esperaria por uma resposta da Ucrânia até às 15:00 locais (12:00 em Lisboa).
O assessor da Presidência russa e chefe da delegação negociadora, Vladimir Medinski, disse, numa declaração a jornalistas na Embaixada da Rússia em Minsk, que aguardaria até às 15:00 locais (12:00 GMT) a confirmação da parte ucraniana de que viajaria até Gomel para as negociações.
Segundo a agência oficial russa TASS, Medinski afirmou que, assim que recebesse essa confirmação, a delegação sairia em direção a Gomel, a cerca de 300 quilómetros a sudeste de Minsk e a 40 quilómetros da fronteira com a Ucrânia.
A delegação russa integra ainda o vice-ministro dos Negócios Estrangeiros, Andrei Rudenko, o embaixador russo na Bielorrússia, Boris Grizlov, e o chefe do comité dos Assuntos Internacionais da Duma (Câmara de Deputados) da Rússia, Leonid Slutski.
"Toda a responsabilidade do futuro desenrolar dos acontecimentos recairá sobre as atuais autoridades da Ucrânia", advertiu Slutski na sua conta do Telegram, perante uma eventual recusa de negociações por parte de Kiev.
A Rússia lançou na quinta-feira de madrugada uma ofensiva militar na Ucrânia, com forças terrestres e bombardeamento de alvos em várias cidades, que já provocaram cerca de 200 mortos, incluindo civis, e mais de 1.100 feridos, em território ucraniano, segundo Kiev. A ONU deu conta de perto de 370 mil deslocados para a Polónia, Hungria, Moldávia e Roménia.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, disse que a "operação militar especial" na Ucrânia visa desmilitarizar o país vizinho e que era a única maneira de a Rússia se defender, precisando o Kremlin que a ofensiva durará o tempo necessário.
O ataque foi condenado pela generalidade da comunidade internacional e motivou reuniões de emergência de vários governos, incluindo o português, e da Organização do Tratado do Atlântico Norte (NATO), UE e Conselho de Segurança da ONU, tendo sido aprovadas sanções em massa contra a Rússia.
Bielorrússia
Rússia e Ucrânia
Volodymyr Zelensky

translated_text:
The War
World
Zelensky says he spoke to the President of Belarus today
Lusa Agency
Feb 27, 2022
12:52
0
Comments
Ukrainian President, Volodymyr Zelensky, said today that he had spoken with his Belarusian counterpart, Alexander Lukashenko, an ally of Moscow and whose country is used as a support base by Russia.
"I spoke with Alexander Lukashenko," Zelensky said on Facebook, without giving details, at a time when Russia insists on possible negotiations in this country.
In a previous statement, the Ukrainian President had stated that his country is ready for peace negotiations with Russia, in Poland, Hungary, Turkey or Azerbaijan, or in any other country, but not "from where they send missiles" towards Ukraine, in a reference to Belarus.
Zelensky reacted, via a video message, to information provided by the Kremlin, according to which a Russian delegation arrived today in the Belarusian city of Gomel for talks with Ukrainian government officials.
Russia declared that it would wait for a response from Ukraine until 15:00 local time (12:00 in Lisbon).
The advisor to the Russian Presidency and head of the negotiating delegation, Vladimir Medinski, said, in a statement to journalists at the Russian Embassy in Minsk, that he would wait until 15:00 local time (12:00 GMT) for confirmation from the Ukrainian side that he would travel to Gomel for the negotiations.
According to the official Russian agency TASS, Medinski stated that, as soon as he received this confirmation, the delegation would leave towards Gomel, around 300 kilometers southeast of Minsk and 40 kilometers from the border with Ukraine.
The Russian delegation also includes the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, Andrei Rudenko, the Russian ambassador to Belarus, Boris Grizlov, and the head of the International Affairs committee of the Russian Duma (Chamber of Deputies), Leonid Slutski.
"All responsibility for the future development of events will fall on the current Ukrainian authorities", warned Slutski on his Telegram account, in the face of a possible refusal of negotiations by Kiev.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused around 200 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported nearly 370,000 people displaced to Poland, Hungary, Moldova and Romania.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for Russia to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), EU and UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

title: Ucrânia . Putin elogia  heroísmo  das forças de operaes especiais
original_title: Ucrânia. Putin elogia "heroísmo" das forças de operações especiais
translated_title: Ukraine. Putin praises "heroism" of special operations forces
original_text:
"E
special reconhecimento àqueles que cumprem heroicamente o seu dever militar no decurso a operação especial para prestar ajuda às repúblicas populares de Dombás", disse o chefe do Kremlin numa mensagem de vídeo aos elementos das forças de operações especiais.
A Rússia invadiu a Ucrânia na quinta-feira, 24 de fevereiro, através da Bielorrússia ao norte, da Crimeia, território ucraniano que anexou em 2014, ao sul, e do território russo a nordeste e a leste.
Na ocasião, Putin anunciou o início de uma "operação militar especial" na Ucrânia, em resposta a um pedido de ajuda das repúblicas populares de Dombás, reconhecias por Moscovo como estados independentes.
As autoridades ucranianas contabilizaram já a morte de pelo menos 198 pessoas, incluindo civis, desde o início da invasão russa.
O ataque russo tem sido amplamente condenado em todo o mundo e vários países, com destaque para os ocidentais, aprovaram sanções económicas para punir o regime de Moscovo.

Resistir até ao fim. Ucranianos tentam parar tanques com as próprias mãos

translated_text:
"And
special recognition to those who heroically fulfill their military duty during the special operation to provide assistance to the people's republics of Dombás", said the head of the Kremlin in a video message to members of the special operations forces.
Russia invaded Ukraine on Thursday, February 24, through Belarus to the north, Crimea, Ukrainian territory it annexed in 2014, to the south, and Russian territory to the northeast and east.
On that occasion, Putin announced the start of a "special military operation" in Ukraine, in response to a request for help from the Domba people's republics, recognized by Moscow as independent states.
Ukrainian authorities have already counted the deaths of at least 198 people, including civilians, since the start of the Russian invasion.
The Russian attack has been widely condemned around the world and several countries, especially Western ones, have approved economic sanctions to punish the Moscow regime.
